cards.title: Notes and queries / Will medical science ever advance to the level it does in Star Trek?
cards.rawTitle: Will medical science ever advance to the level it does in Star Trek?

item.title: Will medical science ever advance to the level it does in Star Trek?
item.trailText: Readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific concepts
item.standFirst: Readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific concepts
item.body:
In the Sky1 series Critical, surgery often looks pretty similar to butchery. Is it feasible that medical science will ever reach the level it does in sci-fi shows and films from Star Trek to Prometheus, where the patient is simply laid out in a glass cubicle and repaired by what look like magical healing energy waves?

Chris Gillespie, Manchester

• Post your answers – and new questions – below or email them to nq@theguardian.com. Please include name, address and phone number

cards.title: Who will be relegated from the Premier League: Hull or Newcastle?
cards.rawTitle: Who will be relegated from the Premier League: Hull or Newcastle?

item.title: Who will be relegated from the Premier League: Sunderland, Hull or Newcastle?
item.trailText: Best XIs from the Premier League, Liga, Ligue 1 and Bundesliga, plus analysis of the relegation battle in England. Will Sunderland and Newcastle be saved by Manchester United?
item.standFirst:
Best XIs from the five biggest leagues in Europe, plus analysis of the relegation battle in England. Will Manchester United save Sunderland and Newcastle?

By Martin Laurence for WhoScored?, part of the Guardian Sport Network
item.body:
The majority of the focus on the Premier League’s final day, as so often proves to be the case, will be on the sides battling against relegation. As things stand it’s a three-way fight to avoid the drop, with Sunderland holding the advantage – as well as a game in hand – over local rivals Newcastle and third-from-bottom Hull City.

Sunderland, 37 points. Remaining games: Arsenal and Chelsea away

Sunderland face an unenviable task at the Emirates on Wednesday night but can take solace from the knowledge that they have held Arsenal to goalless draws in three of their last six trips to North London. If they manage the same feat this time around, Dick Advocaat will have steered the club to safety in the space of just eight matches. It’s also worth noting that Arsenal have drawn a blank in both of their last two home matches.

Sunderland have managed to pick up just eight points from the last 60 available against Arsène Wenger’s side though. If the league had started at the turn of the year, Arsenal would be top on goal difference, despite having played one game fewer than their rivals. They have only won one of their last four matches but Arsenal have been the strongest team this year, with a score of 7.27.

If Sunderland lose to Arsenal, they will have to travel to the champions in the hope that they will recreate the shock victory that helped secure their survival late last season. The result effectively ended Chelsea’s title hopes and José Mourinho is not the sort of manager who forgives and forgets. He will demand that his side sign off in style before the trophy presentation, especially in light of their defeat to West Brom last time out.

Nevertheless, aside from their humiliation at Southampton early on in the season, Sunderland have been well organised away from home. They have only lost more away matches than the Premier League’s current top four (six), while only five sides have conceded fewer goals on their travels (23).

Newcastle, 36 points. Remaining game: West Ham at home

On paper, a home match against mid-table West Ham looks to be among the most favourable available, with the Hammers having picked up the fourth fewest points in the league since the turn of the year (16). Unfortunately for Newcastle their points haul in that time, under head coach John Carver, places them bottom of the league with just 10, and their defeat at QPR on Saturday showed their inability to pick up any sort of result right now.

Newcastle’s recent record against West Ham doesn’t make for great reading either, with the one win they have secured in their last five meetings also the only match in which they have scored against them in in that time. A point would not be enough to secure their safety if Hull beat Manchester United, due to Hull’s significantly superior goal difference (-17 to -25).

Sam Allardyce does not exactly hold fond memories from his time at Newcastle and will be keen to avoid a third successive defeat in what could be his final game in charge of West Ham. Newcastle should not expect any favours from their opponents.

Hull City, 34 points. Remaining game: Manchester United at home

Hull City have it all to do. While they will be praying for Arsenal to beat Sunderland on Wednesday for obvious reasons, a victory for the Gunners would mean that United will finish fourth, subsequently entering the Champions League qualification phase. Such an outcome could have a baring on Louis van Gaal’s team selection, though he is unlikely to field a weak side given the quality he has at his disposal; best highlighted by the fact that a player of Angel di Maria’s quality cannot make the starting XI.

Steve Bruce has no such luxuries but will take confidence from the fact that United have won just six and lost five of their 18 away matches this season. That said, Bruce has never managed any side to victory against his former – from 20 attempts in the league – so now would be a hell of a time to register his first.

A win is a necessity for Hull but it will not guarantee their survival. In seven Premier League meetings with United, they have lost every one and while a rating of 6.92 is enough to place them 15th, above both Sunderland (6.88) and Newcastle (6.87), it appears they have left themselves with too much to do.

cards.title: Cities / London's local markets under threat from gentrification – readers' stories
cards.rawTitle: London's local markets under threat from gentrification – readers' stories

item.title: London's local markets under threat from gentrification – readers' stories
item.trailText: From Brixton to Hackney, are the forces of regeneration spelling an end to traditional markets? You shared your stories and pictures with GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: From Brixton to Hackney, are the forces of regeneration spelling an end to traditional markets? You shared your stories and pictures with GuardianWitness
item.body:
The once-thriving Kingsland Waste market has only one stallholder left due to local regeneration and changes in council policy. It’s not the only market in London under threat of disappearing, as others face the impacts of rising prices, private development and gentrification.

We asked you to share your stories about local markets you love and feel are under threat, as well as how markets in London are changing. Here’s a selection of your responses, from displacement in Brixton to the sanitisation of Shepherd’s Bush.

Brixton market

In Brixton, about 30 shops that currently are located in the arches under the railway are being evicted by the Network Rail and the local council in the new year. Many of these have been around for decades, are family businesses that span generations. They have continued to provide a service to the community over the years and contributed to the vibrant culture of the area. As in many other regeneration plans, the outcome will inevitably result in unemployment, displacement and stripping yet another neighbourhood of its unique character.

- l carlos

Nag’s Head market

It will be replaced with some sanitised, middle-class vision of what a market should be like

bromptonrhodes

Shepherd’s Bush market

Golborne Road market

Kingsland Waste market

Related: Long-time east Londoners on Hackney hipsters: 'They need a humour injection'

Looking back ...

I lived near Broadway Market in the late-70s/early-80s and there was a wonderful piece of graffiti which said: “Broadway Market is not a sinking ship, it’s a submarine”. Went back last year and found they were right! I miss all the old London markets I knew in the 70s and 80s, including the Waste. It is a shame that they have, in the main, become as gentrified as the incomers who now frequent them.

- Helen121

The disappearance of “traditional” London life is making for a less interesting city. As for the continued gentrification, god help us! Soon London will simply become a working class free zone.

- Happyhead16

headerImage.caption: Brixton market: ‘John has been at the arches for 15 years.’ Photograph: l carlos/GuardianWitness
headerImage.cleanCaption: Brixton market: ‘John has been at the arches for 15 years.’

cards.title: Open thread / Which dead British artist would you like to see on the new £20 note?
cards.rawTitle: Which dead British artist would you like to see on the new £20 note?

item.title: Which dead British artist would you like to see on the new £20 note?
item.trailText: The Bank of England has asked the public to nominate a favourite British artist to replace Adam Smith on the £20 note. Tell us your choice
item.standFirst: The Bank of England has asked the public to nominate a favourite British artist to replace Adam Smith on the £20 note. Tell us your choice
item.body:
The Bank of England is asking the public to nominate a new face to go on the £20 note. The currency currently features the economist Adam Smith, but will be changing over to a new design in the next three years. The plan is for the note to feature an artist, which could mean an architect, a potter, a craftsperson or a painter. The governor of the Bank of England urged people to consider artists: “beyond the most obvious and most famous”. He added that they would also have to be deceased.

Who would you like to see on the £20 note? Is there an artist that you feel has been long overlooked in the UK? Tell us who you would choose to represent British art.

cards.title: Olive Cooke death / Does fundraising regulation need reform?

item.title: Olive Cooke death: does fundraising regulation need reform? Open thread
item.trailText: The role of charity fundraisers has come under question following the death of Britain’s longest serving poppy seller. Share your views on what the sector’s response should be
item.standFirst:
The role of charity fundraisers has come under question following the death of Britain’s longest serving poppy seller. Share your views on what the sector’s response should be

  • Regulator probes reports Olive Cooke was distressed by charity requests
item.body:
The death of Olive Cooke, Britain’s oldest poppy seller and long term charity donor, has provoked an outcry.

Mrs Cooke, who was found dead last week in the Avon Gorge in Bristol, reportedly felt tormented by the number of fundraising requests from a wide range of charities, and those closest to her believe it may have contributed to her distress.

Over the last few days the media, politicians and members of the public have called for greater control over charities’ fundraising communications with those who might be vulnerable. Regulators the Fundraising Standards Board and the Institute of Fundraising are to review practices and charities who may have contacted Olive Cooke in the months leading up to her death have begun to review their communications with her.

With this in mind, is it time for the charity sector to reconsider how it approaches donors, especially those who might struggle to say no? Is the current code of practice robust enough? Should there be more detailed guidance for fundraisers?

Share your views in the comments section below and tell us whether fundraising regulation needs an overhaul to address these issues.

For more news, opinions and ideas about the voluntary sector, join our community – it’s free!

displayImages.altText: Poppy seller Olive Cooke pictured collecting donations for the Royal British Legion.

headerImage.caption: Olive Cooke, who died aged 92 last week. Photograph: SWNS.com/SWNS.com

cards.title: EU referendum / Are you seeking a second passport or nationality because of concerns over the UK’s EU status?
cards.rawTitle: Are you seeking a second passport or nationality because of concerns over the UK’s EU status?

item.title: Are you seeking a second passport or nationality because of concerns over the UK’s EU status?
item.trailText: We’d like to hear from people who are considering moving or getting dual nationality in case Britain leaves the EU
item.standFirst: We’d like to hear from people who are considering moving or getting dual nationality in case Britain leaves the EU
item.body:
With Britain’s membership of the EU more precarious than at any point for 40 years, we want to hear from people actively considering moving or getting citizenship to cover for all eventualities.

David Cameron’s commitment to having a referendum on Britain’s membership of the EU, could result in the UK’s relationship with the Europe changing dramatically. It’s unclear what this might mean for EU migrants living in the UK - and for Brits living in Europe. Currently there are 14 million EU citizens residing in another member state and a British exit could require a whole new set of rules governing economic migration, visas and leave to remain.

Free movement – that’s the ability to live, work and study anywhere in the Union could be restricted and future migration into and out of the UK could theroretically be regulated by British national law. In an extreme scenario, British people could end up having to apply for visas every time they travel across the Channel. And Brits already living in other EU countries such as Spain may face integration rules, such as a requirement to speak the language of the host country, before gaining long-term residency status. Access to education, healthcare and welfare could also be in doubt.

We’d like to hear from people who’re concerned about what a future UK exit from the EU would mean for them – both Brits living in Europe and EU migrants to the UK. Do you feel it’s important to get dual nationality now? Have your applied for a second passport? Are you making plans to acquire citizenship? We’d also like you to tell us about your situation – are you married or in a relationship with someone from another European member state? Perhaps you’re working in the UK but your family resides elsewhere. We’ll be looking for contributions to include in an article reporting on these issues.

You can share your perspectives via GuardianWitness by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’.

If you’d prefer you can fill in the form below. You don’t need to supply your real name, but please do leave contact details if you’re happy for us to get in touch. You can also email us at guardian.witness@theguardian.com
